issues.title: How to deal with errors and EAP failure
issues.author: dangarciacarrillo
issues.body:
We can use Message_3 error or generate directly EAP failure
This discussion also applies to message_1

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Add text explaining why the contents in EDHOC error message may be needed.

E.g. EDHOC ERR_CODE 3 "Unknown credential referenced" indicating that
the endpoint who sent the credential identifier should, for the next EDHOC session, try another credential identifier supported according to the application profile.

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body: One question here: In EDHOC, if there is an error , does the EDHOC state machine always generate a error message?

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
"Except for processing and formatting errors, it is up to the application when to send an error message. Sending error messages is essential for debugging but MAY be skipped if, for example, an EDHOC session cannot be found or due to denial-of-service reasons"
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9528.html#name-error-handling

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body: Are we assuming that EAP-EDHOC is the "application" here? I am asking because from that text in EDHOC it seems there are two cases, where an error message can be generated or not.  If both cases might happen within EAP-EDHOC (if EAP-EDHOC is the application and would opt for sending the error)  we should mention it. Not only that, Fig. 5 is problematic since the EAP server will not know what happens with message_4 processing caused a failure but and edhoc error was not generated by the EDHOC implementation.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
I think we should consider EAP-EDHOC as the "application" of EDHOC, although there may be other "applications" that are also involved in policy decisions. I agree we should be explicit about sending errors.

I didn't understand the issue with Fig. 5. Regarding EDHOC implementation sending an error, Section 5.5.3 states:
"If any processing step fails, then the Initiator MUST send an EDHOC error message back as defined in [Section 6](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9528.html#error), and the EDHOC session MUST be aborted."

Regarding your previous question about state machine, maybe these diagrams are helpful. 
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9528.html#name-example-protocol-state-mach

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body: By explicitly sending errors there are no issues and figures do not need any modification.

issues.title: Channel Binding
issues.author: dangarciacarrillo
issues.body:
It would be interesting to discuss if channel binding is worth to be added to the current document.  
Using EAD_3 and EAD_4 might be possible to have an easy solution.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Good to discuss channel binding. 

Two ways to do this inside EAP-EDHOC, here exemplified with SSID:
1. define new EAD item EAD_opaque_data
EAP-EDHOC inserts EAD_opaque_data=SSID

The receiver always needs to verify the provided SSID is legitimate.
Note that for EAD_4 is not included in derivation of MSK.

2. EAP-EDHOC set context = SSID ... 

Note that in this case they need to agree in the SSID out of band.

Alternatively, the application can verify outside of EAP-EDHOC, for example with KDF (MSK, SSID,... )

comments.author: rml1977
comments.body:
RFC 6677 provides a solution for providing EAP channel binding inside the EAP method. That is, alternative 1. Moreover it  defines a format for transporting the information (Figure 2: Channel-Binding Encoding), which is not based on CBOR of course. RFC 6677 says "The transport protocol SHOULD provide confidentiality" for the privacy issue. Since EAD_3 and EAD_4 are good places to exchange the channel binding protection. 

It is also mentioned that "... after
   sending a protected indication of failed consistency, the EAP server MUST send an EAP-Failure message to terminate the session." That happens with in EAD_4 , the EAP peer will answer with the typical empty EAP-EDHOC message and the EAP server will give an EAP-Failure.

In my opinion, it would be easier to provide something as EAP-GPSK does in section 12.3 by saying that EAP-EDHOC provides a way of transporting channel binding information in EAD_3 and EAD_4 using a bit string , we define a new ead label but we do not define anything else.  We would say in the Channel Binding security claims "Extensible" as EAP-GPSK does "The design of EAP-GPSK allows to securely exchange information
      between the EAP peer and the EAP server using protected data
      fields.  These fields might, for example, be used to exchange
      channel binding information or to provide support for identity
      confidentiality."

comments.author: dangarciacarrillo
comments.body:
That sound good to me. 
It would also be good to present the idea at the IETF and see the response.

comments.author: francislopezg
comments.body:
I am reopening this issue following the latest comments from Marco Tiloca. I have added the following text to define the new EAD item for conveying EAP Channel Binding information in the EAD fields, in alignment with Section 3.8 of RFC 9528:

"This new EAD item is intended only for EAD_3 and EAD_4. Then, it MUST be ignored if included in other EAD fields. This new EAD item is considered as non-critical. Multiple occurrences of this new EAD item in one EAD field are allowed."

However, we still need to agree on this. Do you think it is correct to define this EAD item as non-critical and to allow multiple occurrences in the same EAD field?
